suv8: Everyday feels like a constant battle that I can't win, and I just have to persevere alone. I transferred to Solent following my first year of Uni @ St Mary's, Twickenham. I started Uni having spent the previous 4 years in the Army. My first year was easy academically, however I started to feel alone. This loneliness carried into my 2nd year, despite moving to the same Uni as my bestfriend. Again, I wasn't struggling academically I getting reasonably good grades for the little to no effort I was putting in. I then got the news my grandad has passed away. And as a result the second semester was a blur which ended fast, and concluded with the drop-out of my bestfriend which left me with housing issues over the summer (we had secured 2 bed together). Over the summer I eventually spoke to my mum and girlfriend about how down and rough i was feeling who advised me to go to the GP (see above). Starting back this third year has been by far the loneliest year so far. I've been playing american football since joining Solent to try improve socialising, however I quit following the news of grandad last year and have suffered a recent dislocated shoulder this year. I've had enough and want to leave, however I'm aware how close I am to finishing and also that I'm tied down financially through tuition fees, loan and tenancy agreement. And while I may want to leave, realistically I can't and that makes everything harder.
suv11: Help controlling my thoughts
suv12: No
suv13: No

suv8:
I've had issues with anxiety which manifests in overthinking, paranoia, irrationality and situational agoraphobia. I also have issues with depression and have been entering states where i feel numb and everything feels pointless. I've had arguments with my boyfriend because I wont want to get out of bed or follow through with plans because there's no point to doing things because there's no point to existence. This leads to arguments and me saying things I don't believe, and has also led to me missing a lot of uni. 
I also find people really difficult to understand, in terms of body language and understanding sarcasm and being able to tell when people are joking or not. 
I also have lots of self esteem issues which mean I am not confident in myself or my actions which means I am constantly doubting everything I do which makes it 100% harder. 
Also I have had issues with identity and dysmorphia, which has shown itself in different ways such as constantly changing my appearance and having issues with control when it comes to food and eating. I have no clue what I actually look like (if that makes sense) because every time I look in the mirror it changes depending on my mental state. (eg looking much much much larger than I am when I'm in a worse place mentally)
I've also had issues with dissasociation, which isnt the worst thing because it made working at a fast food place more bearable because I wouldnt remember my shift by the time I got home, but sometimes I have increasing sensations of derealisation and depersonalisation which mean I miss entire conversations and sometimes hours of time without remembering what happened or feeling as though I'm actually participating in my own life.
suv11: I just want some help, I have tried going to cbt at my college which didnt work, possibly through me not knowing enough about me and my issues to eloquate them properly, and I've tried going to the drs but they sent me to an online chatroom to talk to people. I want someone to listen and try to help me figure out wtf is up with me (pardon my french) and how I can fix it, because this isnt on and I want to get better.

2019 now- recognise some mild symptoms of depression returning.  Coming to terms with the fact life events & level 7 study is not working for me right now.
Flare up of Mild Depression 2017-
Suspended MSc study towards end of 1st  semester.  Combination of feeling pressure of assignments & difficulty of Level 7 study & father-in-law, acting as carer for his wife with Mid Stage vascular dementia, hospitalised requiring my family to step in as acting carers for a week.
Mild Depression 2015-
In 2015 after both parents passed away within 3 months of each other, whilst significant changes in work structure & role.
suv8:
I would like to talk before reaching a decision on Withdrawal from the MSc.
1.	The MSc Level 7 study is a stretch for me.  I do not feel well aligned to the subject matter of Data Analytics Engineering.  Each unit on its own is within my reach, but combined I feel too stretched (Under strain).  When programming to the level of the MSc units it can take me many hours to come to a solution, leaving me disorientated physically for a while.
2.	Looking after my son can be a challenge sometimes. The thought of doing my dissertation during the summer school holidays, whist looking after him next year, feels totally impractical.
3.	Family pressures of elderly in-laws, with Vascular Dementia fluctuates. Crisis still happen, which involve stepping in.  This influences level of time & energy I can give to MSc.
4.	I am not enjoying the MSc.  No one’s fault.  Just the way it is.
suv11:
Someone to talk to in reaching a decision on the study of MSc. It is important to me I reach a decision that is right for me.
 I appreciate all the support from the University course leader & lecturers, but after discussing this with family & friends & University support I feel the right action for me at this time is to Withdraw from the course.  I am happy to take the 60 credits I have achieved on this course and draw a line under it.
I’ve learned a valuable set of lessons.  Research this size of commitment more carefully in the future.  Gain a better understanding of my new vulnerabilities and take time in aligning myself to new ventures, such as a return to work, with care.

suv8: On Saturday, March 23, 2019 a young man was stabbed near my hall of residence (David Moxon Student Residence). He made it to the door of my residence, where I found him being helped by another student who was unable to control the bleeding, and it was clear that he needed more help. I am trained as a Wilderness First Responder, and so I got my medical kit from my room, ran back down and using my supplies and training applied a compression bandage to control his bleeding, getting my hands covered in his blood. I then assessed his level of awareness and orientation and concluded that he was A&O times 1 (minimally conscious and only able to respond non-verbally at that time). He had lost a massive amount of blood, much of which was pooled around his body, smeared on the glass door, and pooled in intervals along the path he took from where he was stabbed. I continued to assist him after the police arrived by trying to stop him from going into shock when the cut off his jacket by wrapping him in my space blanket. Only when the ambulance arrived, at least 20 minutes after I first arrived at the scene, I removed myself from the care of him.

suv8:
I would like the opportunity to speak with a qualified professional within the university to better understand my emotions and thought processes. I would class myself as mentally sound and I am confident I do not present a risk to myself or those around me.

However, I have become more aware of the competing demands on my time and while making good progress with my PhD, conscious that I have recently not dedicated as much time as I should to it. This time has predominantly been consumed by additional workplace demands which subsequently leave little motivation to begin study when I finish work for the day. For wider context alongside my study I work 2 jobs, both of which have not only continued but intensified throughout covid. One being in the family manufacturing business on a part time basis and the other working full time in a business support function of an FE college.

It is normal for me to reach burnout once a year where my body requires 24 hours to recover. My last burnout was November 2020 but hit me differently in that I didn’t recognise I had reached burnout and it lasted a few weeks rather than a single day as a result. I put this down to a different working pattern during covid.

During our initial session I would also like to explore my relationship with my friend Sophie. I would like to explore the dynamic of this relationship/friendship and the contribution this has to my overall mental state and longer term plans.

Comparing my levels of happiness and confidence in life direction now compared with 5 years ago or even the last 3 years, I feel my life plan is less defined and therefore this need to regain future security impacts upon the decisions I feel I need to make in the present.

This is a top level overview of what I would like to discuss and am sure wider topics will be addressed during the session.
suv14: The opportunity to have an open discussion to better understand the current state of my mind, where appropriate label my current state and to identify steps I need to take for a more stable mental mindset going forwards. Looking for an initial session unless you feel following this session that repeat meetings would be beneficial.

When I get depressed about being the last thought of others, it does make me sad, and angry; yet I know that I shouldn't. My living arrangement currently isn't good either, I was ousted by people who I thought were my friends, and they used my name as an scapegoat to badmouth my now ex-flatmate, who then made a claim against me to my building, who removed her, but told me that I was not to talk to any of my flatmates. I listen to any rule I'm given, but when it gets to the point of being shouted at for "ignoring" my remaining flatmate, and not being allowed to response, I feel dread and upset as to not being able to response; it doesn't help that my ex-flatmate even after 6 months is still going around telling the people of the building untrue heinous things about me to this day, some people who I have met, and have later been told these things, defend me, as I am not whatever she is saying about me; but the idea of someone promoting a negative agenda about me makes me upset. It is not that I am aiming for perfection, but having people hate me for seemingly no reason is something that hurts. For the record, I am not physically angry, or inflicting self-harm on myself, it is just internal anger, which is built upon every memory I have, just consolidating into one giant cloud of doom; my insecurity of life just makes me angry with myself, and depressive episodes seem to come and go when I just want to be happy with myself.

suv11: This academic year has been incredibly difficult for me for a multitude of reasons. Before the year started there were timetabling issues for one of my units leading to pressure and deadline issues. This was accentuated by my becoming severely unwell from mid December right on till early March. The beginning of last week my grandfather died and I have not allowed myself to grieve for him yet due to uni deadlines which I am struggling endlessly to meet. All the while struggling at work with my colleagues and a live in roommate I have struggled to support. I would like support so that I can help to clear my mind and re attain focus, positivity and hope for the direction I would like my life to go.
suv12: I consider myself to be particularly introverted, despite commanding a degree of skill in speaking and writing. Over the course of the year I have had no time to myself to unwind or relax. I gave refuge to a friend whilst he was looking for elsewhere to live due to difficult circumstances in his life, but he is a transitioning male and prone to violent mood swings and emotional blackmail. I dealt with this at home and it was always waiting for me there. When not at home I would either be at work or uni, where again, social interaction could not be avoided for better or worse. Work remains particularly difficult due to my having nothing in common with my work peers. I'm left feeling ostracized and unwelcome the vast majority of the time. There are many other contributing factors, but the fact remains that my head, and indeed mental state, has suffered an intense lashing of inescapable negativity for the space of a year or so. I am very much at my wits end and a complete mess besides.
suv13: After my previous experience with counselling, I was left with a renewed sense of purpose and direction. I also came to learn certain things about myself which would likely not have happened had I not spoken at length with someone who listened. This is very much what I need right now and would do a world of good to getting me back on track.
Course: BA Hons English and Creative Writing

suv8: No
suv11:
I’m a mature student who 16 years ago had to drop out of the final year of my studies due to depression and to become the primary carer of a disabled parent. That depression had been brought on by the combination of a spectacularly soap opera worthy end of a relationship, the sudden death shortly after that of one of my closest friends who I talked to about those things, and the increasing issues of my mothers health and related matters.
I’ve been a carer for around 15 years, which, pretty much meant my social life reduced and got smaller while my friends grew up, moved on, and engaged with life.  My mother passed away, I’ve tried restarting my life but got somewhat burnt out on the job hunt going nowhere, I’ve had another significant relationship end, and I’ve just returned to university in an attempt to actually move on.
Over the past few months I;ve recognised I’ve been dancing around the lines of depression once more, I'd like to be pre-emptive in making sure it doesnt go further.
suv12: I’m nearly twice the age of pretty much all my current “peers” which makes it somewhat harder to engage socially with them. After 15 years as a carer, I’m a little socially withdrawn with a minimal support network. I have the occasional obsessive/circular thought process, along with the odd cognitive/emotional dissonance. I’ve been told I’m emotionally detached, I can bounce from fidgety to stillness. My sleep patterns can be a little off. I’ve “lost” half my life while everyone around me was moving on, and I do have that “who the hell am I now?”anxiety/question.
suv13: Not 100% sure to be fair. Someone to engage with, a means of verbalising it all. An experiment in resocialisation. A way to make sure I don’t actually fall off the motivational wagon and find myself screwing up because I get lost in depression once more. Steps on the path to finding a way back into life without always just putting on a mask of charm and occasional wit. It just seems a tad better idea to try something rather than nothing.

suv8: I am struggling to come to terms with my family disowning me. I was raised as a Jehovah’s Witness and was disfellowshipped back in 2015, which means that nobody from my (JW) friends and family can contact me anymore. I have never looked for help of a professional to help me process this, I thought I can do it on my own and had made good efforts on my own although the first months were the worst… I struggled with alcohol and drug abuse; I’d take anything just to take my mind off it and in my mind, I would sleep with strangers to distract myself and I sometimes still crave that. Now and I don’t do drugs and can drink in moderation, however the demons keep coming back like waves, sometimes they’re stronger than other times. I get anxious a lot, my thoughts get stuck on a loop. Recently I started dating someone who I really care about and would like to form a healthy relationship with them… however my behaviour is smothering and attention seeking, I feel like I’m pushing them away as I’m redirecting all of the attention I would give to my family to this one person and it’s all too much too soon and I am worried that I will lose her.  The thought of my past affecting my future in such respect made me consider seeking help. I want to leave that part of my life behind and although I really miss my brothers and my parents and all of my more distant family I cannot live my life pretending to believe something I just don’t… They won’t speak to me until I go back which I’m afraid is never. I feel like I’m missing out on their lives and I hate myself for not being able to live up to their standards. When I’m at my worst I allow my thoughts to wonder about how much easier it would be to just not have to deal with any of that, indefinitely… but I like to think that there is a good future for me, and maybe one day I’ll have my own family. I think I need to stop escaping this issue and deal with it, but I just don’t know how…
suv11: I’d like to learn how I can properly deal with my past; I’d like to know how to stop these waves of overwhelming sadness and not allow for it to affect my future, my behaviour or the ones I care about. I’d like the horrible thoughts to go away for good, I want to concentrate on the future, I want to be able to do good in life and stop overthinking everything I do and say, I don’t want to push people away and I don’t want them to leave me… I want to be how I was before I was disfellowshipped, grounded, strong… I’d never think I’d need someone’s help with these things…

suv11:
I need help with coping with my anxiety. I have been struggling with it for 8-10 years now, and whilst is comes in waves, it is not going away.

It stops me from doing things like seeing my family, hanging out with friends, going to new places, and going to work. My main coping mechanism is to retreat, and this is holding me back from doing things that I should want to do and enjoy. 

I know what kind of things trigger my anxiety, but I’m not sure how to keep that under control. I am also unsure of why my anxiety ‘come in waves’ (I have good and bad days/weeks quite randomly). 

A GP, amongst other people, have recommended counselling to me, and I think I have spent a long time trying to cope with, or running away from, my anxiety on my own, and now I need some professional help.
suv12:
When my anxiety ‘spikes’ I don’t have a coping mechanism for it, and it effects every aspect of my life (work, study, social and day-to-day), and this makes it difficult to do otherwise ‘normal things’. 

For example, I have a job this summer working in a supermarket, and certain aspects of the job are leaving me on edge my entire shift, and I find I am forcing myself to do what I have to, rather than knowing it’s all just part of the job. It is exhausting. I simply cannot explain to my co-workers why I don’t like certain aspects of the job; it’s embarrassing. Coupled with that, I have a fear of getting things wrong, and that also triggers my anxiety. As I said before, my only coping mechanism is to retreat, and that is just not practical.
suv13:
I need a better way of coping with my anxiety and stresses. Things like hanging out with my friends, going to new places (like other peoples houses) and turning up for work, should not be as hard as it it. And whilst I want to do those things, my anxiety makes me want to literally run away from them.

I know the things that make me uncomfortable, but my friends who aren’t going through the same thing don’t understand that about me. If I also had a better understanding of my anxiety and how to cope with it, it would make it easier to explain to my friends when/why I am having a hard time.

suv8: So last year I used this service and found it to be incredibly helpful. However there were more issues that I had than I was aware of, so while overall it was beneficial I believe that I would benefit from talking about things in more detail. So last year I attended because I was suicidal as a child as a result from bulling and never processed it properly. Now my general well-being is better but I feel like there are still some areas that need addressing. These being issues concerning my poor opinion of  myself. I'm a Christian and struggle with self acceptance because I'm stuck in this unfortunate bind of wanting to act "perfectly" and having the understanding that this is literally not possible. I am also an over thinker which leads to unnecessary stress and worry. I was also diagnosed with a learning difficulty in November 2018 (dysgraphia) and I still feel like its a sensitive topic for me. I'm open about it and I don't exactly keep it a secret, but when people act like its not a big deal just because i have coping mechanisms or that they can't see it, i find to be really frustrating.  I'm a very happy person and I thoroughly enjoy life but I just feel that there are certain aspects of my life that I have tried addressing myself and failed to deal with it, which is why I would like to use this service.

suv8: I find emotions, whether they be my own or others, very confusing and sometimes terrifying. This often causing me to shut down in situations where talking to someone may help, causing me to attempt to deal with things alone. Due to this I also find it difficult to assert myself in situations that cause me emotional distress or even in simple day to day activities. This makes me feel isolated even when there are people who say they want to help because I don't want to burden them or make decisions that upset them even if it is what is right for me. In turn this causes me to pretend to be happy or laid back about decisions or events even if they upset me and doesn't allow me to properly process my emotions before blocking them out or shutting down.

suv8: Yes, growing up as a teenager, I've made numerous attempts on my life. What could be considered the first attempt was when I was around 14/15 or so when I deliberately overdosed on a variety of medication, from what I can barely recall the reason I did so was because I had a complete emotional breakdown at the time. The next attempt I can recall was when tried hanging myself when I was 17 (I think) after a mixture of stress, relationship troubles, emotional difficulty and a bunch of other internal issues. The next attempt I can recall was after drinking heavily at a party instead of heading home, I went to a bridge overarching a dual carriageway, pushed myself onto the railings and was so incredibly tempted to jump down into the traffic below. Aside from alcohol, the reason I did so was due to the other issues I've mentioned previously.
suv11: Because I can't keep going on like this. It's clear to me that I can't solve these problems myself, when I do it's usually in a way that is ultimately self destructive (drug abuse, self harm, etc). My solution seems to be that I have to run away from my issues but it's clear that doesn't solve anything, it only prolongs the suffering. I feel the path I'm walking is only going to lead to oblivion and I don't want that anymore. I want to be better.
suv12:
It's affected my productivity with university because why work when I can just drink the assessment away? Yeah, it's clear that by heading down the downward spiral is only going to worsen my performance and spoil the whole reason I am here in the first place. 
On a similar note, it is terribly affecting the relationships I hold towards my friends, peers and a lesser note family. It feels at times like I'm this poison, a poison that the further you interact with it, the further the infection spreads. And I greatly fear that I'm only going to destroy the personal relationships I hold so dear to me just because of my own self-destructive tendencies. 
One final point is that in terms of my own physical health and lifestyle, I am literally killing myself. All the drinking, smoking, reckless spending and everything else, it isn't good for me. It's not good in the short run and it's not good in the long run.
suv13: At it's core, I would like the ability to regain control of my life and want to shape myself into a better person. I want to be better, to myself and towards others.

suv8: In the past I have had a history of struggling with dealing with my parent's divorce and behaviour that often leads to me being caught in the middle and being forced to act like the adult in the family, this has triggered intense feelings of anxiety and phases of being incapable of doing anything. Despite the divorce being 7 years ago, I still find myself unable to move on due to the fact that I am constantly dragged back into the bickering and fighting of my parents. This feeling of emotional turmoil and emotional whiplash has only gotten worse despite me finally being old enough to move out and try and distance myself from the scenario. At this moment in time I have felt everything starting to get overwhelming again as my mother has decided that with Brexit she needs to move back home to Germany, but this has all been a very complex process riddled with obstacles (including my father refusing to let one of my brothers move with her) and she seems incapable of doing anything without my help. On top of this, my grandparents in Germany no longer know how to help my mother either as she has a very difficult character and have essentially tried passing all responsibility onto me to ensure that she moves within the next couple months. I know that this technically should not be my responsibility, but I find myself in a position where I no longer know what to do with myself and am feeling immense anxiety and pressure from all angles.
suv11: I would like to gain the ability to deal with my anxiety and feelings of guilt in regards to my home situation. I often seem to absorb the feelings of others and then try and fix their issues in an attempt to alleviate any negative feelings they are experiencing and often I suffer as a result.
suv14: A couple years back when my father decided I was lashing out and being a difficult daughter, him and his girlfriend (who claims to be a therapist) tried forcing me to go to therapy. This was all a complete disaster and ended with me not talking to him for the better part of a year. Since then I have actively tried avoiding therapy, but recently I have noticed my emotional state deteriorating and think I would benefit from having some actual help dealing with my unresolved feelings that have been building up from the past, as I feel that if I don't confront them now they may overshadow the rest of my adult life.

- In January, i had issues with a flat mate, who ended up threatening to stab the entire flat, mentioned me by name repeatedly, and did attempt to stab another flat mate with a pair of kitchen scissors
- About summer exam season last year, my Uncle had a heat attack.
- My father and i had an argument, when he refused to be my garuntaur for accommodation, and due to lack of wanting to go back into shared living due to prior experience, left me with nowhere to live.
- My Nan's cancer was diagnosed as terminal over the summer, with a maximum of a 5 year life expectancy. 
 
There are other reasons, but these are the main ones which i would feel comfortable discussing outside of another person directly.

suv8: In November 2019 my dad had a heart attack now since then he has been placed in permanent care which has affected me really hard. As it was me and my Dad together for a very long time. My Dad got re married and me and her never really saw eye to eye. During the first lockdown I went back to live at home due to the fact my step mum was pregnant at the time, and I wanted to be able to support her and my new baby brother as I got a job and made sure bills, electric and food was available for us. After sometime the council contacted her regarding moving, as we were the only family left in our flat. I thought we were all going to be housed together, but little did I know she asked to be housed separately. I tried to contact the council but they told me that I'm not a main priority as I was over the age of 18. Leaving me to fend for myself  only a week to get my stuff moved, because I was planning on studying at home during to everything online. That changed and I quickly had to find a accommodation, and contacted family but we are not as close as we were when we were younger. They said no to help and I had to hire a moving to help me move to my accommodation, during this time my step mum cut off any forms of contact with me. At my accom I have also been struggling with rent but I applied for a loan from the uni and just waiting for a reply and I have asked family and friends but no one can help and I just feel like it getting too much for me as this is all affecting my studies and me soo much.  Also at this time my tendency in my accom  finishes in July and I don't know where I am going to sleep after it ends un less I can get a loan from the uni.
suv11: Just need someone to talk to and get stuff off my chest and try to move on and progress with my life

suv8:
I depersonalised quite a bit, I've been trying to go back to my life but since then I haven't been myself, I'm constantly confused, feeling ''high'' on a bad trip, or just incredibly off while also feeling relatively collected, my frame of mind is changing constantly and I feel  tired and almost ''seasick'' by the constant movement, combined with a new found tendency to irritability, now I get fired up quite quickly which didn't used to be part of my personality, also I'm jumpy, dizzy, weak...
I've been trying to understand why or to what extent I feel out of touch and I can't quite comprehend it, which is part of the main problem, I found some of my feelings to be similar to when a word looses meaning after saying it for too long, I think it's fatigue but most guesses feel the same, there are bits and pieces of my internal compass still missing, meaning that I find myself doubting about how I feel about concepts a lot more, to the point I can't reach conclusions by just thinking about it, I find myself thinking like I would on a dream where I'm conscious about dreaming, also similar to having many drinks and being tired, but sobering up, washed out, or at least that's what I think, I can't quite compare them in my head yet since I'm in such a strange state of mind. I might be miscalculating. also, I feel like I can't know for sure when I'm gonna be hungry or tired on the day or what could make me feel better, or even how I compare to feelings that I had in the past, if only a couple of hours apart, like my insights or self knowledge are very weak, and mostly connected by logic and memory instead of a more natural ''I just know'' manner.
The problem is first of all, my distress since I don't know what is going on and even if it is getting better, I just assume it will, and that it just me being mentally exhausted, still depersonalising, or both, secondly it gets really hard to functions since I feel like I'm on a completely different dimension every couple of hours.
suv11: Helping me understand my situation since I'm running on a series of unreliable guesses, tools to help me function and a structure for me to get my life back safely.

Then after few months I discovered that he was married and got a child and lives with them.
I was shocked. How can someone do that to someone else daughter ? How dare you ?
However, I couldn't stop loving him.
I am still in love with him actually even though I do not speak to him anymore... I blocked him on facebook then unblocked him then blocked him again.

I ignored all the red flags for him. I forgot all my standards and he just played with me. Everyone in my family warned me about him. I didn't listen to anyone. Now I regret. suv8:
2 years ago, I was part of a crash where a bike tried to overtake me but crashed and the rider died graphically. After that I was told I'd receive some kind of counselling through where I worked at the time, but this never happened. Fast forward to now I sometimes feel like I didn’t really process it but rather repressed it. My emotion range is limited I find it hard to find things that make me feel happy. I have things I find myself wanting to do but I can't really say they make me happy as such. They just give me something to do to turn my brain off from thinking. Not really about the crash, which only very occasionally comes to mind unless I'm driving and a bike overtakes me, more just other bad things in the world. They don't even need to affect me directly. It could just be seeing a politician lying on TV or a sob piece about climate change etc. It's injustices that don't directly affect my life so shouldn't illicit such a negative emotional reaction. I also suffer from a short temper for minor things.

In other situation I have this unintentional apathy to things I hear that should upset me but don't.

I have trouble focusing on work where there isn't a clear method. My stability subject questions are easy to focus on as they're very procedural but with other subjects that are more knowledge / research based my mind tends to wonder and get distracted. I find myself researching something related but not what I need to be doing but reading that is somehow something my brain will happily focuses on. This isn't a big problem I only mention it in case it's a sign of something else.

I find myself putting undue attention or fixation on things that don't matter. Overthinking things like buying a phone case without looking into all the options or overthinking if it’s exactly what I want. It’s a £5 phone case, if its somehow wrong you can send it back even if you can’t it’s a fiver it will not affect your life to the amount that you need to overthink this much.

 Sorry for this long amount of context, but I have a bad past with depression & anxiety. I too have been in and out of hospital due to physical manifestations of what’s in my head. suv4: I have previously been told by several doctors that I show several sign of major depressive disorder or chronic depression. I must have first been told such in 2017 around November.
suv8: Generally, I feel very split. I have a very bubbly and energetic personality, loads of ambitions and dreams, however my mental health interferes with everything. I stopped enjoying things that made me me, struggle to get out of bed, struggle to do normal day to day things, most days I won't eat anything until 6pm when I finally gain the courage to leave my room. I am not an anxious person whatsoever but my head definitely gets in the way of my social relationships. I have to stay busy all the time or asleep otherwise I don't feel safe within my own presence, similarly, I will either be completely numb and cold towards life and others or overly emotional and overwhelmed by a number of different things. I also dissociate a lot which is probably one of the things I struggle most with because most of the time I don't actually know if what I am experiencing is real or not which I fear may lead to impulsive decisions as I do not fear the consequences. Furthermore, whenever I am around people or even in lectures my mind will completely wonder and I will feel extremely out of body which is why I don't bother attending anymore. I have tried grounding techniques however many don't work and the ones that do can turn destructive very quickly. Furthermore, I am aware I sabotage myself in terms of my own recovery, I am fully aware and conscious of what I have to do to get better however I don't feel like there is a point in doing so, most of the time I just ignore any type of rational thinking and do whatever I feel like I want to do even if I don't really want to do it.
suv11: Just to feel safe, although talking therapy and counselling has very rarely actually helped, the aftermath of it allows me to be in my own thoughts in a much safer way where I can come to terms with my own next steps whilst still ensuring I am being healthy. It also gives me a reason to get out of the house as I know if I didn't come to sessions my mother would worry even more.
suv12: I do have a whole plan of how I would take my own life, during the 6 years I have been dealing with this it has been one of the most persistent issues I have had and ever since I started medication it actually stopped, until very recently. I do not self harm as I don't find that it helps me in any way, whenever I am upset I do feel the urge to drink to just get away from my emotions. The reason why I haven't attempted to kill myself yet is purely because I know I wouldn't fail if I tried, and I am not ready to give it all up yet. Although there is nothing in life that excites my mind deep down I know I am still the same ambitious person I used to be, and that I do still want to do all the things I planned to do with my family, and for my family.

suv8: Yes - On and off since age 20. Recently lost my cousin to suicide (June) which has made the situation feel a lot worse, however have never felt about trying anything.
suv11: Since becoming a ‘Suicide Victim’ I have found it incredibly hard to motivate myself to attend university, feelings of anxiety come on daily when trying to prepare myself to attend & feelings of loneliness and depression come and go as they please.
suv12: I feel that this could affect my overall degree however it also impacts me daily when trying to achieve any ‘normal’ tasks like going shopping, to the gym and in crowded public spaces. These feelings did not used to be as bad however since the Suicide I have felt like I’m almost in a bubble and unable to think for myself.
suv13: I would like to feel normal again and be able to get on with my life, acceptance of what has happened and the ability to move forward.

suv4: I was diagnosed with General Anxiety Disorder when I was around the age of 9 or 10, however it hasn't been reviewed or updated since, and was worst from ages 9 til 14.
suv8: I am experiencing often periods of anxiety and sadness with my life, roughly 2/3 times per week. This usually happens at night, and I feel like I get lost in my own thoughts. There are a few people I feel I can trust to talk about these issues, and it's got to the point where things have worsened and I feel like I need more professional support. I often think about previous life events, and end up ruminating on negative thoughts and feeling surrounding these events. This can lead to an immense feeling of self hatred and lack of self worth.
suv11: I feel like i need to have someone to talk to, to get feelings off my chest, and to develop better coping mechanisms, and gain a greater understanding of how i process thoughts and feelings.
suv12: My eating has always been quite disordered, but I have noticed I'm eating less recently without a change in appetite. I struggle to prepare meals as well. I have self harmed twice in the last month due to these thoughts of self hatred and self worthlessness.
suv13: I haven't had serious thoughts about suicide or attempted to take my own life, but I've definitely had lingering thoughts about what happens after death, which sometimes pops up during my bad periods.

suv8: I am experiencing a mountain of issues including, mental health difficulties, assignment pressures, issues with my family and this is all very overwhelming and it is affecting my wellbeing.

suv11: Advice on how to cope with my current mindset. Maybe a diagnostic if needed.

I only eat 1 meal most days, hardly ever have an appetite.
suv13: Have never attempted to take my own life or have ever planned to but I have frequently thought about dying.

suv8:
I’ve had problems with my mental health since around 2015/16 and while it got better in between, from 2018 on it came back really heavy around the winter time. In 2015/16 it began with Depression and I went to two different therapists. But after it got better I stopped going, but in October 2018 it got pretty bad again. It also wasn’t Depression any more. I don’t really know how to describe it, I mean I kinda know but I find it hard to write. It is like I have another person or personality in my head/mind. I can hear them, feel them and for example while I used to self-harm because I didn’t know what to do or I felt depressed etc. now it’s not really me anymore but that thing in my head. In general because of this I have trouble concentrating and focusing a lot, I often need to distract myself and stuff. It’s so weird to write this.
Last summer I started to go to a new psychiatrist and talking about it helped I guess. And because it helped I thought this would maybe help as well. Also because I really don’t know what to do, it just feels like I don’t have full control I guess.

Oh and in case you are wondering, I just joined Solent as a 3rd year student this year, because I did my first two years at a college in Germany.
suv11: I don't know if I should put it here, but I would like to speak with a therapist. It helped in the past and I thought I could wait it out longer, but I really can't.
suv14:
In the phase with Depression I was actually diagnosed with severe Depression and the psychiatrist wanted to give me antidepressents. I just learned this in 2018, because my parents didn’t tell me about it and because shortly after the diagnosis it got better it became irrelevant. 

Also the psychiatrist I was with last year kind of came to the conclusion that it’s not really a personality disorder and not really schizophrenic I guess. We also did a ECG (I think that’s what is it called) which didn’t show anything not normal. I don't know if this is important, just thought I'd let you know.

suv8:
I am referring myself as I want to find ways to cope with being alone. Most of my anxiety comes from overthinking about the smallest things and this always happens when I am sat by myself. When I'm around people, I always forget about my thoughts and problems. I am also a very co-dependent person so I would like to know how to enjoy my time alone instead if using it to overthink. 
One thing that I always think about is the way that I come across to other people around me. Depending on who I am with, I can be quite a loud person and I get worried that this may come across as annoying. I also struggle with my body image so I find myself comparing myself with others.
suv11: Independent skills, how to deal with my sleep paralysis, feeling more confident, being able to sit alone and not overthink.
suv14: I struggle to get to sleep because I overthink. I've also started to experience 'sleep paralysis' again. I used to have this when I was younger but I didn't realise what it was until I got older and started researching into it. When I first had it, I used to dream about a dark figure watching me from the corner of my room which made it difficult for me to sleep. It was like every time I closed my eyes, I would see it. Whenever I have sleep paralysis now, I can see myself sleeping in bed but it's like my soul has left my body which makes me feel like I'm dead. I end up having trouble breathing but I try and tell myself to calm down which never works. When I do eventually wake up, I'm always sweating. I have noticed that these episodes last between 5 to 15 minutes even though it feels longer.

Typically, what I will do is cut my upper arms (and sometimes thighs) with razors multiple times, as this allows me to deal with the urge, without running the risk of people seeing or visible marks being left as the cuts tend to be quite superficial, and heal quickly.
suv13: Yes. I attempted to take my own life when I was 15 (cut my left wrist with an X-acto blade - only stopped as a friend threatened to call an ambulance, and I felt ashamed and panicked about the thought of the ambulance arriving whilst I was still alive, and my mum finding out). I have also thought about it a number of times since then, but have never had a concrete plan to do so. In an odd way, it is sometimes a comforting thought to have, as it feels like it's always there as a back up.

suv8: I have never tried any mental health support session in my life but I think I might benefit from it. I suffer from long Covid, especially the fatigue connected to it, which makes my overall energy levels and motivation very low. That causes me being not as active with my dissertation (due on 2nd September) as I should be, which makes me feel guilty, very stressed and anxious. I cannot even enjoy free time activities anymore, because all my thoughts are just: "You should focus more on your dissertation, don't be so lazy!“ But I constantly feel too tired to put much effort into it and my hobbies don't even make me relaxed anymore because of all the guilty thoughts racing in my head, so even my free time feels like a chore. I feel like my heart is constantly racing and my stomach and chest is kind of squeezed, it feels like being in the "fight or flight" mode constantly which is draining my low energy even more. I also have trouble falling asleep even though I am so tired, it usually takes me between 1-3 hours because my mind keeps worrying. And when I finally do a bit of work, it makes me even more stressed because I feel like the workload is too much and there is no way I can do high-quality work with my stressed mindset, so I am at the point when I just want to pass even with the lowest pass grade but I am not even sure I can do that.
suv11: I would like to get some advice on how to manage my stress, anxiety and how to stop the negative self-talk in my head. I believe that without these negative feelings and with some routine in my daily life I might be able to finish my dissertation on time even with the ongoing fatigue.

suv8:
Often, I experience changes within my mood and they vary between feeling very low and/or sad (sometimes without an explanation), sometimes I am very hyper and happy, I can get angry easily and often go into bad moods too. Recently, I have experienced a kind-of anxiety like thing where in some situations I feel very anxious and nervous, when I haven't really felt like this before. I'm also incredibly 'jumpy', perhaps skittish is the word.
Most of the time, I find it very hard to motivate myself to do anything. for example, it's difficult getting out of bed most days and I rarely feel like I have had enough sleep and I constantly find myself napping, usually every day for up to three hours. I then sleep for another 7+ hours at night. Sometimes I find it hard to get to sleep - this may be caused by napping in the day or to my thoughts not letting me sleep - usually I'm angry or overthinking certain situations. 
Situations I think of in my head sometimes feel like they're real and they make me feel very strong emotions - like anger or anxiety or sadness. Sometimes, I feel compelled to join in these conversations in my head. This is not something that outright affects my life it just makes me personally feel uncomfortable.

Months ago, I was prescribed some antidepressants to help with symptoms of PMDD. I think it helped with some symptoms but not others and after a couple of months I stopped taking them altogether.
I feel like I experience the symptoms I was having all the time now rather than just premenstrual. For the past two weeks, my mood swings have been extreme and erratic, transitioning from one mood to the next in around 30 mins - 1 hour. I have gained 3 stone in 3 years because of food cravings I cannot control and I feel food has become to me what alcohol is to an alcoholic. It leaves me concerned about my long term health.
suv11: I am reluctant to go back to my doctor with this issue as I don't want to feel pressured into taking medication. I feel I need support with mindset and changing behaviour and perhaps addressing issues of the past

suv8: I have a history of PMDD and my symptoms have recently become worse. I have spoken with my GP who has prescribed Sertraline and made a referral to my local gym for support with exercise but has also recommended that I seek some talking therapy alongside this and I hoped this might be accessible through the university as I have spoken with James about this in the past.
suv11: I'm not sure what I can gain from talking therapy as the whole point of this problem is that the ability to make conscious choices and use coping strategies is overridden by these symptoms, I don't choose these behaviours, they happen with such force - however, I am following my doctor's advice to get back in touch.
suv14:
My most recent concern is the damage I could be doing to my long term health as a result of PMDD. This week I had to see a doctor after finding blood in my stools and having stomach pains for 1 -2 weeks. She examined me and said I was constipated with hemorrhoids and recommended taking laxatives. At the same time, my period is due next week and one of my most extreme symptoms of PMDD is binge eating - which has probably caused me to become constipated. I have called in sick at work today because I have a severe headache, tummy pain and awful lower back pain where my kidneys sit which worrys me about the damage I am doing to my body because I can't control myself. 
I joined Slimming World three weeks ago and began losing weight, then I reach this stage of my menstrual cycle and I completely lose control. I feel like I've been hit by a train and it's exhausting trying to wake up and find a good day to start again knowing I'll be reliving this in a few weeks time. 
I have been prescribed two different anti-depressants which I have been reluctant to take after reading about common side effects, such as a feeling of numbness, loss of emotion and weight gain. After speaking with my GP today I have agreed to try Sertraline for days 15 - 28 of my cycle to be reviewed in 2-3 months.

Since I found out I can deal with my mental health andI've been experiencing high levels of jealousy to a point where it becomes toxic without a particular reason. I can't even enter my boyfriend's house without a desire to leave immediately or stay and cry instead. The house has turned into the darkest side of my mind. 

On top of that, I started feeling dependant on my boyfriend for my mood and general mental health and I'm experiencing hyperventilation or close to panic attack situations almost all the time when he's not around me. 

During the last session we discussed and found out how possibly the problem originated but now I feel hopeless and desperate to save my relationship because I can feel that I'm hurting my boyfriend constantly when I feel jealous. I can't recognise myself at this point and low self-esteem and confidence were not something common for me before that happened.

suv8:
It all began as tension and anxiety, provoked by my inability to sustain myself, due to the fact I wasn't able to find a job after the winter break. Then I started to feel nervous being around people, and I started isolating myself occasionally in order not to make my friends feel distressed or moody because of my problems.
 
The turning point when I realised I had a problem was after a talk with one of my flatmates and my mother. They told me that I look really anxious and asked me how do I feel. Then I wasn't able to answer. I only new that I don't feel ok, and it's now becoming a problem because I have absolutely no motivation for being productive, no matter if it comes to my studies or my social life. 

The main thing that worries me lately is my genuine fear of death. When I say fear i mean something more than that. I've had it since I was 8 but now sometimes when I think about this topic I see my life just passing for a second in my head and then when I see\feel the blank space after it I start shivering and I can't breathe properly for several seconds until this thought is out of my mind. It's like a minor panic attack but i'm afraid that it can grow into something more serious. 

I generally i think i'm just emotionally and energetically drained.
suv11: I would like to get to my previous state of mind as fast as possible so I can be able to balance my life again. I need this constant thinking about "what happens after I die" and the inability to answer that question to stop torturing me so i need a way to kick those out of my mind.

suv12: I have had suicidal thoughts for a few years now but for the most part I can deal with them but when I get stressed or sad the frequency in which I get them increases and it can be disturbing. When I get in this state I worry if one day I may follow through although I do somewhat enjoy life maybe one day is just too much for me to handle. I don't really self harm but I've noticed that when I get angry I want to punch walls or through things maybe even hit my head, I feel like it's more simple things I don't notice like snapping an elastic band on my wrist which at first seems like fidgeting as I am a big fidgeter  but then I realise I am actually causing myself pain. I for the most part can control these outbursts of anger or urges to hurt myself but if I am particularly sad or stressed it becomes increasingly more difficult to control and I have to almost physically restrain myself. I never used to have thoughts of hurting people that I am aware of but recently I have been hurting people in my dreams, at first I wasn't too disturbed as it was people I did not like and I knew I wouldn't actually do anything in real life but then I hurt one of my friends in my dreams and they hadn't done anything to annoy me recently and that was quite disturbing and upsetting as I wish no ill will onto them. In terms of thoughts of harm to people when I'm awake I do believe I get intrusive thoughts which for the most part I can handle and ignore but they do sometimes disturb me when I imagine random people or people I care for being injured by myself or a random occurance. I'm not addicted to any drugs or alcohol but when I am particularly stressed or sad I do find myself seeking out or wanting to numb myself but again for the most part I can control it.

On the other side, I never think I'm good enough. Whatever I do, it's just not enough. I've only been here for four months and seeing everyone so well adapted and ready, makes me feel like I will fail. I can't express myself in classes properly, and my English are not that bad.

suv4: I have been through 6 month residential rehab for alcohol addiction, in 2015.
suv8:
I came in to speak to a student adviser (Haley) last week. She was extremely kind, professional and helpful. I am a mature student coming back in to education after ten years of alcohol dependence. I feel overwhelmed and a mixture of "I don't deserve this" and "what if this doesn't work out?"  I have worked as a Mental Health Recovery Worker for two years and it is a job that feel passionate about. The week before I left full time work to come to uni one of my clients died. Although I was able to look at this professionally, I have been left with a sense of guilt, having left my colleagues to deal with the aftermath, as it where. I have also felt a dip in my motivation, and I have toyed with the idea of not coming in some days. I can feel lots of emotions and thoughts piling up one on top of another and I do not want to get to a point where I explode and drop out. I have a lot of fear surrounding dropping out, as I tried to do uni twice in my twenties, but as a result of my substance misuse, dropped out. I can feel that I am being hard on myself, but I can also (at this point) imagine a future whereby this is quite possible. 

I'm also finding it quite difficult to recall and write down all the things that I spoke to Hayley about. There's a lot more.
